Meanwhile, a war over the digitized souls of the dead is expanding from cyberspace into the real world. }} {{Book list/sublist|List of Culture series | title = ''[[The Hydrogen Sonata]]''<ref name="Banks2012HydrogenSonata">{{cite book |last=Banks |first=I.M. |title=The Hydrogen Sonata|publisher=Orbit |year=2012 | isbn=978-0356501505 }}</ref> | publish_date = 2012 | aux1 = 2375 CE (approximate)<ref>The book states that the Interesting Times Gang from ''Excession'' has not been seen in almost 500 years; also, that it is about 1000 years after the Idiran war.</ref> | isbn = 978-0356501505 | line_color = novel | short_summary = In the last days of the Gzilt civilisation, which is about to Sublime, a secret from far back in their history threatens to unravel their plans. Aided by a number of Culture vessels and their avatars, one of the Gzilt tries to discover if much of their history was actually a lie. }} |}</onlyinclude>
==Main themes== Since the Culture's biological population commonly live as long as 400 years<ref name="Johnson1998ExcessionReview">{{cite web |url=http://www.sfsite.com/03a/exc28.htm |title=SF Site Featured Review: Excession |last=Johnson |first=G.L. |year=1998 |accessdate=2009-02-15}}</ref> and have no need to work, they face the difficulty of giving meaning to their lives when the [[Mind (The Culture)|Minds]] and other intelligent machines can do almost anything better than the biological population can.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infinityplus.co.uk/nonfiction/windward.htm |title=''Look to Windward'' – a review |last=Shoul |first=S. |accessdate=2009-02-15}}</ref> Many try—few successfully—to join [[Contact (The Culture)|Contact]], the Culture's combined [[diplomacy|diplomatic]] / [[military]] / [[governmental|government]] service, and fewer still are invited to the even more elite [[Special Circumstances]] (SC), Contact's [[secret service]] and [[special operations]] division.<ref name="Banks1996Excession"/> Normal Culture citizens vicariously derive meaning from their existence via the works of Contact and SC. Banks described the Culture as "some incredibly rich lady of leisure who does good, charitable works... Contact does that on a large scale."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.richmondreview.co.uk/features/banksint.html |title=A Quick Chat With Iain M. Banks |publisher=The Richmond Review |accessdate=2009-02-15}}</ref> The same need to find a purpose for existence led the Culture as a whole to embark voluntarily on its only full-scale war, to stop the expansion of the [[theocratic]] and [[militaristic]] [[Idiran]]s—otherwise the Culture's economic and technological advancement would have been a pointless exercise in [[hedonism]].<ref name="Banks1987ConsiderPhlebasIdiranWar"/>
All of the stories feature the tension between the Culture's humane, [[anarcho-communist]] ideals and its need to intervene in the affairs of less enlightened and often less advanced civilisations.<ref name="Brown1996UtopiasAndHeterotopias">{{cite book |last=Brown |first=C. |title=Impossibility Fiction |editor=Littlewood, D. |editor2=Stockwell, P. |publisher=Rodopi |date=September 1996 |pages=57–73 |chapter=Utopias and Heterotopias: The 'Culture' of Iain M. Banks |isbn=90-420-0032-5 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NznwlEC5jVQC&pg=PA1&dq=culture+%22iain+m+banks%22+ |accessdate=2009-02-15}}</ref><ref name="Gevers2000LTWReview">{{cite web |url=http://www.sfsite.com/11b/lw93.htm |title=SF Site Featured Review: Look To Windward |last=Gevers |first=N. |year=2000 |accessdate=2009-02-15}}</ref> The first Culture novel, ''[[Consider Phlebas]]'', describes an episode in the Idiran War, which the Culture's Minds foresaw would cause billions of deaths on both sides, but which their [[utilitarian]] calculations predicted would be the best course in the long term.<ref name="Banks1987ConsiderPhlebasIdiranWar"/> The Idiran War serves as a recurring reference point in most of the subsequent novels, influencing the Culture's development for centuries and dividing its residents—both humanoids and AI Minds—along the pacifist and interventionist ideals.
In subsequent novels, the Culture—particularly SC and, to a lesser degree, Contact—continue to employ subterfuge, [[espionage]], and even [[Direct action (military)|direct action]] (collectively called "dirty tricks") in order to protect itself and spread the Culture's "good works" and ideals. These dirty tricks include blackmailing persons, employing mercenaries, recruiting [[double agent]]s, attempting to effect [[regime change]], and even engaging in [[false flag]] operations against the Culture itself (potentially resulting in the death of billions).<ref name="Brown1996UtopiasAndHeterotopias" /><ref name="Banks1996Excession" /><ref name="Banks1988PlayerOfGames" /> Though each of these individual actions would horrify the average Culture citizen, the Culture's Minds tend to justify these actions in terms of lives saved in the long-term, perhaps over the course of several hundred years. The Culture is willing to use not only preemptive, but also retaliatory actions in order to deter future hostile actions against itself. Banks commented that in order to prevent atrocities, "even the Culture throws away its usual moral rule-book."<ref name="GravitasShipNames" /> Andrew M. Butler noted that, "Having established the peaceful, utopian, game-playing tendencies of the Culture, ... in later volumes the Culture’s dirty tricks are more exposed."<ref name="Butler2003British Boom">{{cite journal |last=Butler |first=A.M. |date=November 2003 |title=The British Boom: What boom? Whose boom? |journal=Science Fiction Studies |issue=93 |url=http://www.efanzines.com/SFC/SteamEngineTime/SET04-2.pdf |accessdate=2009-02-14}}</ref>
The Culture stories have been described as "eerily prescient".<ref>{{cite book |last=Baker |first=N. |title=The True Knowledge of Ken MacLeod|editor=Butler, Andrew M. |editor2=Mendelsohn, F. |publisher=Science Fiction Foundation |location=Reading, UK |year=2003 |pages=95–97 |chapter=Review of Dark Light}}</ref> ''Consider Phlebas'' explicitly presents a [[clash of civilizations]],<ref name="Duggan2007BanksPostmodernismAndGulfWar" /> although this phrase was coined by [[Samuel P. Huntington]] in 1992.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aei.org/publications/pubID.29196,filter.all/pub_detail.asp |title=Samuel P. Huntington, 1927–2008 |date=14 January 2009 |publisher=American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref> This is highlighted by the novel's description of the Idirans' expansion as a "[[jihad]]" and by its [[Epigraph (literature)|epigraphic]] verse from the [[Koran]], "Idolatry is worse than carnage".<ref name="Duggan2007BanksPostmodernismAndGulfWar">{{cite journal |last=Duggan |first=R. |date=22 December 2007 |title=Iain M. Banks, postmodernism and the Gulf War|journal=Extrapolation |url=http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-7634299/Iain-M-Banks-postmodernism-and.html |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref><ref>"Idolatry is worse than carnage" is a much quoted translation of the Koran 2: 190, but modern scholars regard it as inaccurate, since the word translated as "idolatry" actually means "discord" or "oppression" or "persecution" – see {{cite journal |last=Duggan |first=Robert |year=2007 |title=Iain M. Banks, postmodernism and the Gulf War |journal=Extrapolation |volume=48 |issue=3 |pages=558–577 |doi=10.3828/extr.2007.48.3.12 |issn=2047-7708 |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Iain+M.+Banks,+postmodernism+and+the+Gulf+War.-a0176374803 |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref> However, it was as much a "holy war" from the Culture's point of view.<ref name="Duggan2007BanksPostmodernismAndGulfWar" /> Throughout the series, Contact and Special Circumstances show themselves willing to intervene, sometimes forcefully, in other civilizations to make them more Culture-like.
Much of ''Look to Windward'' is a commentary on the Idiran-Culture war, from a viewpoint 800 years later, mainly reflecting grief over both personal and large-scale losses and guilt over actions taken in the war. It combines these with similar reflections on the catastrophic miscarriage of the Culture's attempt to dissolve the Chelgrians' oppressive caste system. In neither case, however, does distress over the consequences of Culture policy lead its representatives to reject that policy. The book illustrates the limitations of power, and also points out that Minds and other AIs are as vulnerable as biological persons to grief, guilt and regrets.<ref name="Duggan2007BanksPostmodernismAndGulfWar"/>
==Place within science fiction== {{main|Science fiction|Space opera}} When the first Culture stories appeared, science fiction was dominated by [[cyberpunk]], a pessimistic subgenre that worried about, but offered no solutions for, the [[offshoring]] of jobs to countries with lower costs or less strict regulations, the increasing power of corporations and the threats to privacy posed by computer networks. The Culture stories are [[space opera]], with certain elements that are free from scientific realism, and Banks uses this freedom extravagantly in order to focus on the human and political aspects of his universe; he rejects the dystopian direction of present day [[capitalism]], which both cyberpunk and earlier space operas assume, in creating a communist society as the primary civilization of focus.<ref name="Mendelsohn2005Excession">{{cite book |last=Mendelsohn |first=F. |title=A Companion to Science Fiction |editor=Seed, D. |publisher=Blackwell Publishing |year=2005 |pages=559–566 |chapter=Iain M.Banks: ''Excession'' |isbn=1-4051-1218-2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HO_z5WFKwpoC&pg=PP12&dq=culture+%22iain+m+banks%22+ |accessdate=2009-02-15}}</ref> Space opera had peaked in the 1930s, but started to decline as magazine editors such as [[John W. Campbell]] demanded more realistic approaches. By the 1960s many space operas were satires on earlier styles, such as [[Harry Harrison (writer)|Harry Harrison]]'s [[Stainless Steel Rat]] and [[Bill, the Galactic Hero]] stories,<ref>{{cite book |last=Westfahl |first=G. |title=The Cambridge Companion to Science Fiction |editor=James, E. |editor2=Mendelsohn, F. |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2003 |pages=197–208 |chapter=Space opera |isbn=0-521-01657-6}}</ref> while televised and film space operas such as ''[[Star Trek]]'' and ''[[Star Wars]]'' were thought to have dumbed down the subgenre.<ref>http://whatculture.com/film/15-blunders-that-ruined-j-j-abrams-star-trek-and-destroyed-the-franchise.php</ref><ref>http://www.depauw.edu/sfs/documents/introduction72.htm</ref><ref>http://macha.itc.griffith.edu.au/dspace/bitstream/handle/10072/31808/59792_1.pdf?sequence=1</ref> The Culture stories did much to revive space opera.<ref name="Johnson1998ExcessionReview"/><ref name="Butler2003British Boom"/>
==Literary techniques== Banks has been described as "an incorrigible player of games" with both style and structure – and with the reader.<ref name="HoltSFX2007Player"/> In both the Culture stories and his work outside science fiction, there are two sides to Banks, the "merry chatterer" who brings scenes to life and "the altogether less amiable character" who "engineers the often savage structure of his stories".<ref name="Sleight2008Matter">{{cite web |url=http://www.locusmag.com/Features/2008/03/locus-magazines-graham-sleight-reviews.html |title=Locus Magazine's Graham Sleight reviews Iain M. Banks |last=Sleight |first=G. |date=March 2008 |publisher=Locus Magazine |accessdate=2009-02-15}}</ref> Banks uses a wide range of styles. ''[[The Player of Games]]'' opens in a leisurely manner as it presents the main character's sense of boredom and inertia,<ref name="Eyrie2005ReviewPlayer">{{cite web |url=http://www.eyrie.org/~eagle/reviews/books/0-06-105356-2.html |title=Review: ''The Player of Games'' by Iain M. Banks |date=18 November 2005 |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref> and adopts for the main storyline a "spare, functional" style that contrasts with the "linguistic fireworks" of later stories.<ref name="HoltSFX2007Player">{{cite journal|last=Holt |first=T. |date=November 2007 |title=Must-read Classic of SF Literature: ''The Player of Games'' |journal=SFX Magazine |pages=114 |url=http://www.sfx.co.uk/resources/sfx/SFX162playerofgames.pdf |accessdate=2009-02-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081010093702/http://www.sfx.co.uk/resources/sfx/SFX162playerofgames.pdf |archivedate=October 10, 2008 }}</ref> Sometimes the styles used in ''[[Excession]]'' relate to the function and focal character of the scene: slow-paced and detailed for Dajeil, who is still mourning over traumatic events that happened decades earlier; a parody of huntin', shootin', and fishin' country gentlemen, sometimes reminiscent of [[P. G. Wodehouse]], when describing the viewpoint of the [[List of societies of the Culture setting#Affront|Affront]]; the ship ''Serious Callers Only'', afraid of becoming involved in the conflict between factions of [[Mind (The Culture)|Minds]], speaks in cryptic verse, while the ''[[Sleeper Service]]'', acting as a freelance detective, adopts a [[hardboiled]] style. On the other hand, Banks often wrong-foots readers by using prosaic descriptions for the grandest scenery, self-deprecation and humour for the most heroic actions, and a poetic style in describing one of the Affront's killings.<ref name="Mendelsohn2005Excession"/>
He delights in building up expectations and then surprising the reader.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} Even in ''The Player of Games'', which has the simplest style and structure of the series, the last line of the epilogue reveals who was really pulling the strings all along.<ref name="HoltSFX2007Player"/> In all the Culture stories, Banks subverts many clichés of [[space opera]]. The Minds are not plotting to take over the universe, and no-one is following a grand plan.<ref name="Mendelsohn2005Excession"/> The darkly comic double-act of Ferbin and Holse in ''[[Matter (novel)|Matter]]'' is not something most writers would place in "the normally po-faced context of space opera".<ref name="Sleight2008Matter"/> Even the [[List_of_spacecraft_in_the_Culture_series|names of Culture spaceships]] are jokes – for example ''Lightly Seared on the Reality Grill'', ''Experiencing a Significant Gravitas Shortfall'' (part of a [[running gag]] in the series<ref name="GravitasShipNames">{{cite web |url=http://homepages.compuserve.de/Mostral/interviews/guardian00.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071124054925/http://homepages.compuserve.de/Mostral/interviews/guardian00.htm |archivedate=24 November 2007 |accessdate=2009-02-15 |title=Iain Banks – Interview}} Originally published in [[The Guardian]], 2000</ref>) and ''Liveware Problem'' (see [[liveware]]).<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2008/feb/09/fiction.iainbanks |accessdate=2009-02-15 |last=Poole. |first=S. |title=Review – "Matter" by Iain M. Banks |date=9 February 2008 |location=London |work=The Guardian}}</ref>
Banks often uses "outsiders" as viewpoint characters,<ref name="Vint2007Bodies">{{cite book |last=Vint |first=S. |title=Bodies of tomorrow |publisher=University of Toronto Press |year=2007 |pages=79–101 |chapter=3 – Iain M. Banks: The Culture-al Body|isbn=0-8020-9052-4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R5PITXl1fSMC&pg=PA79&dq=%22Iain+M.+Banks%22+culture+outsider |accessdate=2009-03-09}}</ref> and said that using an enemy of the Culture as the main character of ''Consider Phlebas'', the first story in the series, enabled him to present a more rounded view of the Culture.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} However, this character realises that his attempts to plan for anything that might conceivably happen on a mission are very similar to the way in which the Culture makes all its decisions, and by the end suspects he has chosen the wrong side.<ref name="Horwich2002CultureClash"/>
The focal character of ''The Player of Games'' is bored with the lack of real challenges in his life,<ref name="Horwich2002CultureClash"/> is blackmailed into becoming a Culture agent, admires the vibrancy of the Azad Empire but is then disgusted by its brutality,{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} and wins the final of the tournament by playing in a style that reflects the Culture's values.<ref name="Horwich2002CultureClash"/>
''Use of Weapons'' features a non-Culture mercenary who accepts the benefits of association with the Culture, including immortality as the fee for his first assignment, and completes several dangerous missions as a Culture agent, but complains that he is kept in the dark about the aims of his missions and that in some of the wars he has fought maybe the Culture was backing both sides, with good reason.<ref name="Horwich2002CultureClash"/>
''Look to Windward'' uses three commentators on the Culture, a near-immortal Behemothaur, a member of the race plunged into civil war by a Culture intervention that went wrong, and the ambassador of a race at similar technological level to the Culture's.<ref name="Gevers2000LTWReview"/>
The action scenes of the Culture stories are comparable to those of blockbuster films.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Palmer |first=C. |date=March 1999 |title=Galactic Empires and the Contemporary Extravaganza: Dan Simmons and Iain M. Banks |journal=Science Fiction Studies |volume=26 |issue=1 |url=http://www.depauw.edu/sfs/backissues/77/palmer77.htm |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref> In an interview, Banks said he would like ''[[Consider Phlebas]]'' to be filmed "with a very, very, very big budget indeed" and would not mind if the story were given a [[happy ending]], provided the biggest action scenes were kept.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sffworld.com/interview/2p1.html |title=Interview with Iain M. Banks |year=2002 |publisher=SFF World |accessdate=2009-02-17}} (page 2 of the interview; page 1 is [http://www.sffworld.com/interview/2p0.html here])</ref> On the other hand, ''The Player of Games'' relies mainly on the psychological tension of the games by which the ruler of the Azad Empire is selected.<ref name="Eyrie2005ReviewPlayer"/>
Banks is unspecific about many of the background details in the stories, such as the rules of the game that is the centrepiece of ''The Player of Games'',<ref name="Eyrie2005ReviewPlayer"/> and cheerfully makes no attempt at scientific credibility.<ref>"I know it's all nonsense, but you've got to admit it's impressive nonsense." {{cite web|url=http://www.futurehi.net/phlebas/text/cultnote.html |title=A Few Notes on the Culture |last=Banks |first=I.M. |year=1994 |accessdate=2009-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322183158/http://www.futurehi.net/phlebas/text/cultnote.html |archivedate=2012-03-22 |df= }}</ref>
==Genesis of the series== Banks says he conceived the Culture in the 1960s, and that it is a combination of wish fulfilment and a reaction against the predominantly right-wing science fiction produced in the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spikemagazine.com/iain-banks-interview.php |title=Iain Banks – Interview |last=Lowe |first=G. |date=24 March 2008 |publisher=Spike Magazine |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref> In his opinion, the Culture might be a "great place to live", with no exploitation of people or AIs, and whose people could create beings greater than themselves.<ref name="Gevers2002CulturedFuturist">{{cite web|url=http://www.scifi.com/sfw/issue274/interview.html |title=Cultured futurist Iain M. Banks creates an ornate utopia |last=Gevers |first=N. |year=2002 |accessdate=2009-02-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002115448/http://www.scifi.com/sfw/issue274/interview.html |archivedate=October 2, 2008 }}</ref>
Before his first published novel, ''[[The Wasp Factory]]'' (1984; not science fiction), was accepted in 1983, Banks wrote five books that were rejected, of which three were science fiction.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spikemagazine.com/0996bank.php |title=Iain Banks : ''Whit'' and ''Excession'': Getting Used To Being God |last=Mitchell |first=C. |date=3 September 1996 |publisher=Spike Magazine |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref> In Banks' first draft of ''[[Use of Weapons]]'' in 1974, his third attempt at a novel, the Culture was just a backdrop intended to show that the mercenary agent was working for the "good guys" and was responsible for his own misdeeds. At the time he persuaded his friend [[Ken MacLeod]] to read it and MacLeod tried to suggest improvements, but the book had too much [[purple prose]] and a very convoluted structure. In 1984, shortly after ''The Wasp Factory'' was published, MacLeod was asked to read ''Use of Weapons'' again, and said there was "a good novel in there struggling to get out", and suggested the interleaved forwards and backwards narratives that appeared in the published version in 1990. The novella ''[[The State of the Art]]'', which provides the title of the 1991 collection, dates from 1979, the first draft of ''[[The Player of Games]]'' from 1980 and that of ''[[Consider Phlebas]]'' from 1982.<ref name="Wilson1994BanksInterview">{{cite web |url=http://textualities.net/tag/iain-m-banks/ |title=Iain Banks Interview |last=Wilson |first=A. |year=1994 |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref>
==Reception== ''[[Inversions (novel)|Inversions]]'' won the 2004 Italia Science Fiction Award for the Best International Novel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfsite.com/columns/news0403.htm |title=SF Site: News (March 2004) |last=Silver |first=S.H. |year=2004 |accessdate=2009-02-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517073827/http://www.sfsite.com/columns/news0403.htm |archivedate=May 17, 2008 }}</ref>
The American edition of ''[[Look to Windward]]'' was listed by the editors of SF Site as one of the "Best SF and Fantasy Books of 2001" after the UK edition had missed out by just one place the previous year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfsite.com/columns/best02.htm |title=Best SF and Fantasy Books of 2001: Editors' Choice |last=Walsh |first=N. |accessdate=2009-02-17}}</ref>
''[[Use of Weapons]]'' was listed in [[Damien Broderick]]'s book ''Science Fiction: The 101 Best Novels 1985-2010''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nonstop-press.com/?p%3D2439 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130426200920/http://nonstop-press.com/?p=2439 |archivedate=2013-04-26 |df= }}</ref>
As a posthumous tribute to Iain Banks, aerospace manufacturer [[SpaceX]] named two of its [[autonomous spaceport drone ship]]s after sentient star ships '''Just Read the Instructions''' and '''Of Course I Still Love You''' which first appeared in the novel [[The Player of Games]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/spacex-sticks-a-rocket-landing-at-sea-in-historic-first/ |title= SpaceX Sticks a Rocket Landing at Sea in Historic First |author= Calla Cofield |date= 9 April 2016 |publisher= Scientific American |work= SPACE.com}}</ref>

|image = [[File:UCMSA Universalis Logo.png|thumb|An unofficial version of the UCMSA Universalis logo, from September 2013.]] |captionstyle = |headerstyle = background:#ccf; |labelstyle = background:#ddf; |datastyle = | alt = A stylised Homo Universalis
|header1 = Association Information |label1 = |data1 = |header2 = |label2 = Full name |data2 = University College Maastricht Study Association |header3 = |label3 = Abbreviation |data3 = UCMSA Universalis |header4 = |label4 = Formation |data4 = {{Start date and years ago|2002|12|03}} |header5 = |label5 = Legal status |data5 = Study Association |header6 = |label6 = Location |data6 = Maastricht, The Netherlands |header7 = |label7 = Membership |data7 = 600-700 |header8 = |label8 = Official language |data8 = English |header9 = |label9 = Affiliations |data9 = [[University College Maastricht]], [[Maastricht University]] |header10= |label10 = Website |data10 = http://ucmsauniversalis.com |header11= Social Board |label11 = |data11 = |header12= |label12 = President |data12 = Ruben D. Payne |header13= |label13 = Secretary |data13 = Mishael Qadeer Warraich |header14= |label14 = Treasurer |data14 = Laura S. Robinson |header15= |label15 = Executives |data15 = Jonathan Schoen, Juliette van den Brule, Esther Salem |header16= |label16 = |data16 = |header17= Academic Council |label17 = |data17 = |header18= |label18 = Chair |data18 = Hannah Rae Savage |header19= |label19 = Treasurer |data19 = Freya Carrington Walker |header20= |label20 = Executives |data20 = Lea Pehnt, Ana Rosas, Erick Jackaman |header21=Communication|data22={{Facebook | ucmsauniversalis | UCMSA Universalis }}|label23=Instagram|data23={{Instagram | ucmuniversalis | UCMSA Universalis }}|label22=Facebook}}
'''UCMSA Universalis''' is a multicultural and multidisciplinary student association directly affiliated with the [[University College Maastricht]]. It is run by UCM students for UCM students and contributes to both academic and social life at UCM. The association is involved in the organisation of debates, poetry readings, open-mic nights, parties, charity fundraisers, student representation, and other events.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maastrichtuniversity.nl/web/Schools/UCM/TargetGroup/ProspectiveStudents1/EducationalProfile/TheAcademicCommunity.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100205021009/http://www.maastrichtuniversity.nl/web/Schools/UCM/TargetGroup/ProspectiveStudents1/EducationalProfile/TheAcademicCommunity.htm |archivedate=2010-02-05 |df= }}</ref> Following a structure typical of [[Maastricht University]] ''study associations,'' it is run by a student board. The Universalis student board consists of a Social Board, an Academic Council, and an Independent Body. Board positions are traditionally a semester to two semesters long. Active members of the association are organised as committees which provide services for all students at the college. All new students automatically become a member upon enrollment at the college.
== Organisation structure == There are currently six members on the UCMSA Universalis Social Board: President, Treasurer, Secretary, External Executive, Social Executive, and Acquisitions Executive. Currently only the President is elected by Universalis members, the rest of the Board are selected by the previous Board and then officialised through a public vote in a General Assembly. Board members serve for one or two semesters after which they can re-apply.<ref>Pot, E.; Pagán, B. UCMSA Universalis Charter, Notarised 3 December 2002</ref> Social Board meetings are held once a week. Universalis's committees and societies operate under the Social Board, who seek to financially and logistically facilitate all committee activities.
The Academic Council works in parallel with the Study Association Board, with five members: Chair, Treasurer, Secretary, Events Coordinator, and External. The Council represents students in working with the [[University College Maastricht]]'s Board of Studies, who are responsible for evaluating academic courses and affairs. They also organize Academic conferences, guest speakers, academic workshops, and student exchanges with sister colleges. The Academic Council is funded by the Social Board, but works in conjunction with the Social Board.
The Independent Body consists of three to five students elected by a general assembly with the goal of keeping the Social Board and Academic Council in accordance with the association's Statutes and Policy Manual. They also serve a functional role in General Assemblies and voting procedures.
== Current Committees and Societies == Arts & Photo Committee

Ludens Games Society: board games and video games
Meditation Society
Music Committee
Musical Committee
Party Committee
Pluralism in Economics Committee (PINE)
Spiritual Enlightenment
Sports Committee
Theatre Society
Wellbeing Committee
== History == At the beginning of September 2002 [[University College Maastricht|UCM]]'s first students gathered in the back yard of the newly founded college. Several students formed an informal ''founding committee'' to get a student society started.<ref>Lucas, G.; Pot, E.; Pagán, B.; Wiebe, P.; Josten, L.; Plenter, J., UCM Study Association Universalis: Annual Report 2002-2003</ref> Because the diversity of [[University College Maastricht|UCM]]'s students and its curriculum, they decided that [[Leonardo da Vinci|Da Vinci]]'s [[Homo Universalis]] was a suitable symbol for the student society's identity. It represents the juxtaposition of different interests in its members and of the diverse [[University College Maastricht|UCM]] student body. The founding committee decided to call the association ''Universalis'' and Brian Pagán designed the logo, a stylised version of the [[Vitruvian Man]]. The first unofficial Universalis general meeting was held on 19 September 2002. The organisation's structure was drawn up by the founding committee and the first board was elected. The organisation was registered with the Maastricht [[Chamber of Commerce]] and certified by a [[Civil law notary|notary]] on 3 December 2002, marking the official establishment of UCM Study Association Universalis.<ref>Lucas, G.; Pot, E.; Pagán, B.; Wiebe, P.; Josten, L.; Plenter, J., UCM Study Association Universalis: Annual Report 2002-2003</ref>
UCMSA Universalis joined University College Student Representatives of the Netherlands (UCSRN) in <year> and has been an active member since.

{{lead too short|date=August 2017}} [[File:Women in military world map.svg|thumb|260px|World map showing the integration of women in the armed forces in 2016{{update inline|date=March 2018}}
{{legend-table|lang=en|title= Women in military world |#5599ff|women not permitted in military. |#ff9955|women permitted in military, no further information |#5aa02c|Women permitted in the military, but treated unequally (for example, not allowed in frontline combat) |#ff5555|Women permitted in the military, treated as equals |#8d5fd3|conscription for women |#b3b3b3|No data, no armed forces, no stable form of government or ongoing/recent policy changes. }}]] {{Women in society sidebar}} Recent history of changes in women's roles includes having [[women in the military]] in many countries. ==Africa== === Algeria === The presence of female soldiers in the Algerian army was of crucial importance during [[Women in the Algerian War|the Algerian revolution]] against colonial France, some of the most prominent figures and symbols of the National Liberation Front were female combatants. [[Fatima Zohra Ardjoune]],{{cite web|author=Par Mounir Kechar |url=http://www.algerlablanche.com/index.php?post/Pr-Fatima-Zohra-Ardjoune%2C-la-premi%C3%A8re-femme-g%C3%A9n%C3%A9ral-de-l-arm%C3%A9e-alg%C3%A9rienne |title=Pr Fatima Zohra Ardjoune, la première femme général de l'armée algérienne - Alger La Blanche - Le Portail de l'Algérie |publisher=Alger La Blanche |date=1999-02-22 |accessdate=2018-10-25}} director general of the Ain Naâdja military hospital, was promoted to general, the first woman in the Algerian People’s National Army (PNA)—and in the Arab world—to reach this rank. Three years later, Fatima Boudouani {{cite web|url=https://www.middleeastobserver.org/2017/03/03/algerias-interest-in-world-security-stems-from-international-solidarity-principle-official/ |title=Algeria's interest in world security stems from international solidarity principle: Official |publisher=Middle East Observer |date= |accessdate=2018-10-25}} became the second woman to be promoted to the rank of general in the [[wikipedia:People's National Army (Algeria)|PNA]], and she was followed by three more women in 2015, therefore becoming the Arab country with the biggest number of high-ranking female army commanders. https://muftah.org/women-in-the-algerian-military-then-and-now/#.WTtiP-s1_IU{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/2014/07/09/Algeria-appoints-four-female-army-generals-.html |title=Algeria appoints four female army generals |publisher=Al Arabiya English |date=2014-07-09 |accessdate=2018-10-25}} Four generals were also promoted to the rank of major-general. {{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Algerian-woman-becomes-countrys-first-female-general |title=Algerian woman becomes country's first female general - Middle East - Jerusalem Post |publisher=Jpost.com |date=2009-07-05 |accessdate=2018-10-25}} Aardjoun's promotion reflects a growing trend of Algerian women taking more prominent positions in the workforce, most notably in the police and military. Algeria boasts the largest number of female police officers in the Muslim world. The status of women in the military had been made legally equal to that of men in an ordinance on February 28, 2006, and the military’s promotions of women from 2009 to 2015 broke an apparent taboo. The army has since put in place a formal policy framework for equal opportunities, and efforts have been made to apply it. Since 2005, Bouteflika has been under pressure to enact more changes in favor of women’s rights. ===Eritrea=== Female soldiers in Eritrea played a large role in both the Eritrean civil war and the border dispute with Ethiopia, because they make up more than 30% of the Eritrean military. They also serve in direct combat operations.{{Citation needed|date=February 2013}} ===Libya=== A 200-strong unit was [[Muammar al-Gaddafi]]'s personal bodyguard and is called variously the "Green Nuns" and "The Amazonian Guard" or more commonly in [[Libya]] [[The Revolutionary Nuns]] ({{lang-ar|الراهبات الثوريات}}) .[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article3052655.ece?token=null&offset=0 TimesOnline: ''Adieu, Colonel Muammar Gaddafi, a tricky guest''] Accessed 29 June 2008 ===South Africa=== [[File:Africa Aerospace and Defense 2010 (5093447570).jpg|thumb|right|Female [[South African National Defence Force]] members speak with an American soldier during the [[Africa Aerospace and Defence]] expo in 2010.]] South African women have a long history of service in the [[South African Defence Force]] (SADF) and in the modern [[South African National Defence Force]] (SANDF). In [[World War I]] and [[World War II]] women served in auxiliary roles in the [[South African Defence Force]] and were assigned to non-combat active roles after 1970. In 1914 a volunteer nursing service was established by the army and 328 nurses to serve with South African troops in [[Europe]] and [[East Africa]] in World War I. The Women's Auxiliary Army Service began accepting women recruits in 1916. Officials estimated that women volunteers relieved 12,000 men for combat in World War I by assuming clerical and other duties. During World War II, South Africa had five service organizations for women—the South African Military Nursing Service, and women's auxiliaries attached to the army, the navy, the air force, and the military police. During the late 1970s and 1980s, women were active in civil defence organizations and were being trained as part of the country's general mobilization against possible terrorist attacks. In 1989, for example, the Johannesburg Civil Defence Program provided training for 800 civil defense volunteers, about one-half of whom were women. These classes included such subjects as weapons training for self-defense, antiriot procedures, traffic and crowd control, first aid, and fire-fighting. An unreported number of women also received instruction in counterinsurgency techniques and commando operations. Women also served in military elements of liberation militias in the 1970s and the 1980s, and women were accepted into the [[ANC]]'s military wing, [[Umkhonto we Sizwe]] (Spear of the Nation, also known as Umkhonto—MK), throughout the [[Anti-Apartheid Movement|anti-apartheid struggle]]. In 1995 women of all races were being incorporated into the [[South African National Defence Force]] (SANDF), and a woman officer, Brigadier Jackie Sedibe, was appointed to oversee the implementation of new SANDF policies concerning the treatment of women. Women had been promoted as high as warrant officers and brigadiers in the Permanent Force by the early 1990s, but only ten women were SADF colonels in 1994. In 1996 Brigadier Sedibe became the first woman in the military to be promoted to the rank of major general. Widespread cultural attitudes in the 1990s still oppose the idea of women in combat, but officials are debating ways to assign women an equitable share of the leadership positions in the military.{{cite web|url=http://www.mongabay.com/history/south_africa/south_africa-women_in_the_military_homeland_militaries.html|title=South Africa-Women in the Military Homeland Militaries|website=www.mongabay.com}} In 2011 almost 26.6% of the uniformed services of the South African National Defence Force consisted of women.{{cite web|url=http://www.defenceweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=16708:fact-file-sandf-regular-force-levels-by-race-a-gender-april-30-2011-&catid=79:fact-files&Itemid=159|title=Fact file: SANDF regular force levels by race & gender: April 30, 2011 - defenceWeb|first=Leon|last=Engelbrecht|website=www.defenceweb.co.za}} ===The Gambia=== [[Military of the Gambia]] have no gender conscription and women are free to volunteer for the armed forces. In 2011 the first female army general was decorated in [[the Gambia]].{{cite web |url=http://observer.gm/africa/gambia/article/gambias-first-female-army-general-decorated |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219015225/http://observer.gm/africa/gambia/article/gambias-first-female-army-general-decorated |archivedate=2013-12-19 |df= }} Accessed 29 June 2008 ===Tunisia=== Mandatory Military Service is required for all Tunisian women since March 2003. Tunisia is the first Arab country to conscript women. ==Asia and Oceania== ===Australia=== {{Main|Women in the Australian military}} [[File:Able Seaman Maritime Logistics-Support Operations Codie-Lee Reid on HMAS Canberra at RIMPAC 2016.jpg|thumb|A female member of {{HMAS|Canberra|LHD 02|6}}'s crew in 2016]] All roles in the Australian Defence Force are open to women. The first women became involved with the Australian armed forces with the creation of the Army Nursing Service in 1899. On the 30th of June 2017, women were found to make up 16.5% of the [[Australian Defence Force]] (with 20.6% in the [[Royal Australian Air Force]], 20.4% in the [[Royal Australian Navy]] and 13.2% in the [[Australian Army]]).http://www.defence.gov.au/annualreports/16-17/Downloads/WomenInTheADFReport2016-17.pdf However, up until 2016, only 74% of the total number of available roles in the Australian armed forces were available to women. Despite this, using 1998-99 figures, the ADF had the highest percentage of women in its employ in the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_Departments/Parliamentary_Library/Publications_Archive/archive/womenarmed |title=Women in the armed forces: the role of women in the Australian Defence Force – Parliament of Australia |publisher=Aph.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2018-10-25}} In 1998, Australia became the fourth nation in the world to allow women to serve on its submarines. Australia was the fourth country to permit female crew on submarines, doing so in June 1998 on board [[Collins class submarine]]s. Australia's first deployment of female sailors in a combat zone was aboard [[HMAS Westralia (O 195)|HMAS ''Westralia'']] in the [[Persian Gulf]] during the [[Gulf War|1991 Gulf War]]. On 27 September 2011, Defence Minister Stephen Smith announced that women will be allowed to serve in frontline combat roles by 2016.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-09-27/women-on-the-frontline/2946258|title=Women cleared to serve in combat|publisher=ABC News|date=27 September 2011}} In 1992, allegations of alleged sexual harassment on board [[HMAS Swan (DE 50)|HMAS ''Swan'']] were investigated, and in 1998 similar allegations arose in the [[Australian Defence Force Academy]]. === Bangladesh === Bangladesh Army started recruiting female soldiers from 2013.[http://www.daily-sun.com/print/back-page/2015/01/30/485112 Serve with professionalism] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20150424065742/http://www.daily-sun.com/print/back-page/2015/01/30/485112 |date=2015-04-24 }}. daily-sun.com. 30 January 2015. Bangladesh Navy's first batch of female sailors completed their training in 2016's May.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/country/navy-gets-first-women-soldiers-1231678|title=Navy gets first women soldiers|date=30 May 2016|publisher=}} ===China=== Female comprise an estimated 7.5% of the [[People's Liberation Army]] forces. ===India=== {{main|Indian Army#Female| label 1 = Women in Indian Army}} [[File:Indian army lady officer.jpg|thumb|A female officer in the [[Indian Army]] briefing Russian soldiers during a joint exercise in 2015.]] The Indian Military Nursing Service was formed in 1888 and nurses fought in World War I and II where 350 Indian Army nurses either died or were taken prisoner of war or declared missing in action, this includes nurses who died when SS Kuala was sunk by the Japanese Bombers in 1942.[http://www.hindustantimes.com/opinion/indian-army-must-stop-its-discrimination-against-military-nurses/story-VmhPT6cKj3GW3M3KjCterK.html Indian Army must stop its discrimination against military nurses], [[Hindustan Times]], 13 December 2017. In 1992, the [[Indian Army]] began inducting women officers in non-medical roles.{{cite web|url=http://joinindianarmy.nic.in/bravo/entry-schemes-women.htm|title=Entry Schemes Women : Officers Selection - Join Indian Army|website=joinindianarmy.nic.in}} On 19 January 2007, the United Nations first all female peacekeeping force made up of 105 Indian policewomen was deployed to [[Liberia]].{{cite news|title=First All-Female U.N. Peacekeeping Force to Deploy to Liberia|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,244862,00.html | work=Fox News Channel|date=19 January 2007|accessdate=28 January 2008}} In 2014, India's army had 3 per cent women, the Navy 2.8 per cent and the Air Force performed best with 8.5 per cent women.{{cite web|title=Indian Army's shameful treatment of women recruits|url=http://www.ndtv.com/opinion/indian-armys-shameful-treatment-of-women-recruits-706717|website=NDTV}} In 2015 India opened new combat air force roles for women as [[fighter pilot]]s, adding to their role as helicopter pilots in the Indian Air Force."India paves way for women in military combat roles" [http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/india-paves-way-for-women/2215380.html ''Channel NewsAsia'' 24 Oct 2015] ===Iraq=== {{Main|Women in Iraq#Women in the Government and Military}} {{Expand section|date=November 2015}} ===Israel=== {{Main|Women in the Israel Defense Forces}} [[File:Israeli military police women stand in formation during an honor cordon ceremony for Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates in Tel Aviv.JPEG|thumb|Israeli military police women (2007)]] Some women served in various positions in the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]], including infantry, radio operators and transport pilots in the [[1948 Arab-Israeli War|1948 war of independence]] and the [[Suez Crisis]] in 1956, but later the Air Force closed its ranks to female pilots, and women were restricted from combat positions. There is a draft of both men and women. Most women serve in non-combat positions, and are conscripted for two years (instead of three years for men). A landmark high court appeal in 1994 forced the Air Force to accept women air cadets. In 2001, Israel's first female combat pilot received her wings. In 1999 the [[Caracal Battalion|Caracal]] company was formed, as a non segregated infantry company. In 2000 it was expanded into a Battalion (called The 33rd, for the 33 women killed in combat during the War of Independence) since then, further combat positions have opened to women, including Artillery, Field Intelligence, Search and Rescue, NBC, Border Patrol, K-9 Unit and anti-aircraft warfare. On May 26, 2011, [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] Chief of Staff [[Benny Gantz]] announced Brigadier General [[Orna Barbivay]]'s appointment as the next Head of the IDF Personnel Directorate. Barbivay was promoted to [[Major General]], thus becoming the most senior female officer in the history of the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]]. ===Japan=== [[File:Jsdf-候補生（新隊員前期）.jpg|thumb|Female candidates of the [[Japan Self-Defense Forces]] (2011).]] When the [[Japan Self-Defense Forces]] (JSDF), postwar armed forces of [[Japan]], was originally formed, women were recruited exclusively for the nursing services. Opportunities were expanded somewhat when women were permitted to join the [[Japan Ground Self-Defense Force]] (JGSDF; army) communication service in 1967, the [[Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force]] (JMSDF; navy) and [[Japan Air Self-Defense Force]] (JASDF; air force) communication services in 1974. By 1991, more than 6,000 women were in the JSDF, about 80% of service areas, except those requiring direct exposure to combat, were open to them. The National Defense Medical College graduated its first class with women in March 1991, and the [[National Defense Academy of Japan]] began admitting women in 1992.{{cite web|title=Japan Focus|url=http://japanfocus.org/-Fumika-Sato/3820|accessdate=2013-01-24}} The first female in the JSDF to achieve star ranks (admiral and general) is [[Hikaru Saeki]], who became JMSDF [[Rear Admiral]] on 27 March 2001.{{Cite news |date=28 March 2001 |script-title=ja:自衛隊初の女性将官が誕生、佐伯光海将補　夫も元海将 |language=ja |publisher={{lang|ja|[[Yomiuri Shimbun|読売新聞 東京朝刊]]}} |page= A. 39}} She was followed by Michiko Kajita and Keiko Kashihara, who were promoted to JASDF [[Major General]]s in 2007{{Cite book |author={{lang|ja|自衛隊の謎検証委員会編}} |title=知られざる自衛隊の謎 |script-title=ja:知られざる自衛隊の謎 |publisher={{lang|ja|彩図社}} |date=October 2011 |page=133 |language=ja |isbn=978-4883928132}} and 2011 respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.e-avanti.com/person/27koro/2334 |archivedate=19 April 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130419052319/http://www.e-avanti.com/person/27koro/2334 |script-title=ja:柏原 敬子さん／社会のために、先駆者として道を切り拓く。 |publisher={{lang|ja|アヴァンティ}} |date=20 April 2012 |accessdate=2 January 2013 |language=ja}} JMSDF Captain Ryoko Azuma became the first woman to command a warship division in March 2018.{{cite news |publisher=Reuters |quote=Ryoko Azuma, will command four ships with a combined crew of 1,000, of which only 30 are women, that make up the Maritime Self Defense Force’s (MSDF) First Escort Division. |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-defence-femalecommander/japans-navy-appoints-first-woman-to-command-warship-squadron-idUSKCN1GI0VC |first=Nobuhiro |last=Kubo |first2=Tim |last2=Kelly |editor-first=Simon |editor-last=Cameron-Moore |date=March 6, 2018 |title=Japan's navy appoints first woman to command warship squadron}} {{clear}} [[Japan Air Self-Defense Force|JASDF]] First Lieutenant [[Misa Matsushima]] became the first woman to qualify as a fighter pilot in August 2018. At that time, the total number of military women in Japan was 13.707, only a little less than 6% of the total force. {{cite web|url=https://www.elconfidencial.com/mundo/2018-08-24/japon-primera-mujer-piloto-de-combate-top-gun_1607461/|title=Una mujer será piloto de combate en Japón por primera vez: soñaba con 'Top Gun'|publisher=}} ===Kazakhstan=== [[File:Kazakh Female Soldier.jpeg|thumb]] Females are allowed to take combat roles in the [[Kazakh Armed Forces]]. ===Nepal=== It is worth noting that Peoples Liberation Army, a guerrilla army fighting the government, have a 30% female participation quota for their combat forces, and frequently claim 40% actual participation.{{cite web|url=http://www.blog.com.np/united-we-blog/2006/07/04/maoist-army-in-writing-interview-with-comrade-commissar/#more-1060 |title=United We Blog! for a Democratic Nepal " Maoist Army in Writing: Interview With Comrade Commissar |publisher=Blog.com.np |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} A proposal of a 40% female combat troop quota in the future [[Nepal Army]] has been frequently forwarded publicly by Maoist leaders during their peace negotiations with the current government. ===New Zealand=== [[File:AK 08-0130-58.jpg - Flickr - NZ Defence Force.jpg|thumb|A female [[Royal New Zealand Air Force]] officer in 2008]] There are no restrictions on roles for women in the [[New Zealand Defence Force]]. They are able to serve in the Special Air Service[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10744070 New Zealand Herald: "Who dares, applies: SAS opens its ranks", 10th August 2011 - "The new policy may also see more women apply, [Major Horn] said. "We haven't had any women so far pass SAS selection. We're really keen to see women apply." infantry, armour and artillery. (So far no woman has yet made it into the Special Air Service.) This came into effect in 2001 by subordinate legislation, with a report in 2005 finding that the move helped drive a societal shift that "values women as well as men" but that integration of women into combat roles "needed a deliberate and concerted effort".{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/13/130125-women-combat-world-australia-israel-canada-norway/|title=8 Other Nations That Send Women to Combat|date=25 January 2013|publisher=}} ===North Korea=== The [[Democratic People's Republic of Korea|DPRK]] allows women to serve in combat roles. ===Pakistan=== {{Main|Women in the Pakistan Armed Forces}} '''Women in the Pakistan Armed Forces''' are the female soldiers who serve in the [[Pakistan Armed Forces]].{{cite web | last =Front Desk | first = | authorlink = | title =Pakistan women officers visit NATO Headquarters | website =North Atlantic Treaty Organization | publisher =NATO Newsroom and North Atlantic Treaty Organization | date = | url =http://www.nato.int/cps/en/SID-483ED6A8-159D9975/natolive/news_70676.htm?selectedLocale=en | doi = | accessdate =September 2, 2012 }} [[Pakistan]] is the only country in the [[Islamic world]] to have women appointed in the high ranking assignments and the [[general officer]] ranks, as well as performing their military duties in the hostile and combat military operations.{{cite news | last =ISPR Officials | first = | coauthors = | title =Pakistan: Woman in running to become first 3 star general | newspaper =Indian Express | location =New Delhi | page =1 | publisher =Indian Express Group of Newspapers | date =September 2, 2012 | url =http://www.indianexpress.com/news/pakistan-woman-in-running-to-become-first-3-star-general/845360/ | accessdate = }} Women have been taking part in [[Pakistan military]] since 1947 after the [[Creation of Pakistan|establishment]] of Pakistan, currently a strong sizable unit of women soldiers who are serving in the Pakistan Armed Forces.{{cite web | title =Pakistan Army | url =http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/pakistan/army.htm | accessdate =2012-09-02 }} In 2006, the first women fighter pilots batch joined the combat aerial mission command of [[Pakistan Air Force]]{{cite news | last =Abbas | first =Zafar | coauthors = | title =Pakistan gets women combat pilots | newspaper =BBC News | location =Islamabad | page =1 | language =| publisher =BBC News, Islamabad | date =30 March 2006 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/4861666.stm | accessdate =September 2, 2012 }} and women in [[Pakistan Army]] have been trained in combat missions, particularly in sniper, airborne and infantry warfare.{{cite web | last =Staff editorial report | first = | authorlink = | title =Pakistan army to turns to women for combat | website =Indian Defence Journal | publisher =Indian Defence Journal | date =April 26, 2006 | url =http://www.india-defence.com/reports-1797 | doi = | accessdate =September 2, 2012 }} The [[Pakistan Navy]] is currently the only uniform service branch where women are restricted to serve in the combat missions especially in the submarine force command, rather they are appointed and served in the operation involving the [[military logistics]], operational planning, staff development and the senior administrative offices, particularly in the regional and central headquarters.{{cite news | last =Staff report | first = | coauthors = | title =Splendid passing-out parade held for smartly turned out naval officers | newspaper =Tribune Express | location =Pakistan Naval Academy | page =1 | publisher =Tribune Express | date =July 5, 2011 | url =http://tribune.com.pk/story/202397/splendid-passing-out-parade-held-for-smartly-turned-out-naval-officers/ | accessdate =September 2, 2012 }} ===Philippines=== {{Main|Women in the Philippine military}} From 1993 onward, women served only in [[Women's Army Corps|Women's Army Auxiliary Corps]] of [[Philippine military]]. In 1993, women were granted the right to serve as combat soldiers with the passage of Republic Act No. 7192 and the first batch started the training in the [[Philippine Military Academy]] in April that year. ===Saudi Arabia=== Applications for certain non-combat roles were opened to women in February, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-43197048|title=Saudi Arabia allows women to join army|date=26 February 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}} ===Singapore=== Singapore allows women to serve in combat roles, although females are not conscripted. ===Sri Lanka=== [[Sri Lanka Air Force]] (SLAF) was the first service of the Sri Lankan military to allow women to serve, accepting female recruits to the [[Sri Lanka Volunteer Air Force]] in 1972. The Sri Lanka Army followed in 1979 with the establishment of the [[Sri Lanka Army Women's Corps]] (SLAWC). Since then, each service has for both administrative and practical reasons maintained separate units for women. These are the SLAWC and the SLAF Women's Wing; the [[Sri Lanka Navy]] does not have a specific name for women's units. In order to maintain discipline, all three services have women [[Military police|MPs]] attached to their respective military police/provost corps. Currently, female personnel of all three services play an active part in ongoing operations. However, there are certain limitations in 'direct combat' duties such as [[special forces]], pilot branch, naval fast attack squadrons. These are only a few restrictions; female personnel have been tasked with many front line duties and attached to combat units such as [[paratroops]], [[Sri Lanka Air Force Regiment|SLAF Regiment]], as well as undertaken support services such as [[Control tower|control tower operators]], [[Electronic warfare|electronic warfare technicians]], radio material teletypewriters, [[Auto mechanic|automotive mechanics]], [[Assault Support|aviation supply personnel]], [[cryptographers]], [[physician|doctors]], [[combat medic]]s, [[lawyers]], [[Combat engineering|engineers]] and [[Aerial photography|aerial photographers]]. In the [[Sri Lanka Navy]] female personnel were at first limited to the medical branch, however currently both lady officers and female rates are able to join any branch of service including the executive branch. With the escalation of the [[Sri Lankan civil war]], many female personnel have come under enemy fire both directly and indirectly thus taking many casualties including fatalities. As of 2008 there were three female officers of the rank of [[Major General]] and one [[Commodore (rank)|Commodore]]. The [[Department of Civil Defence (Sri Lanka)|Sri Lanka Civil Defence Force]], formerly the Sri Lanka Home Guard, has been open to women recruits since 1988. In 1993, these guardswomen were issued firearms and deployed to protect their home towns and villages against attacks by [[LTTE]]. As a result, there have been many casualties (including fatalities) from attacks. ===Thailand=== Thailand has recently begun recruiting and training women to conduct counter-insurgency operations (c. 2007).{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/asiapcf/03/18/thailand.women.ap/ | work=CNN}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} A ranger commander said that when women are protesting, "It is better for women to do the talking. Male soldiers look tough and aggressive. When women go and talk, people tend to be more relaxed". === United Arab Emirates === [[File:Khalifa Academy Graduation.jpg|thumb|260x260px|Emirati female cadets parade during a graduation ceremony at Khalifa bin Zayed Air College.]] The UAE hosts the Gulf region’s first military college for women, Khawla Bint Al Azwar Military School has been open since 1991 under the late [[Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan]]. Females were granted the same training and responsibilities as their male counterparts, and also play a major role in humanitarian assistance and peacekeeping operations. Emirati women have reached senior ranks within the [[UAE Armed Forces]], especially in the Air Force combat units. A great example of the achievements of Emirati women is Major [[Mariam al-Mansouri]], The first female fighter pilot in the [[United Arab Emirates]] and the [[Arab World]]. She made international headlines for leading the UAE's mission to fight ISIS.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/uae/government/emirati-woman-who-reached-for-the-skies|title=Emirati woman who reached for the skies ... {{!}} The National|website=www.thenational.ae|access-date=2016-05-19}}{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/uae/general/uae-women-prove-competency-in-military-1.1045873|title=UAE women prove competency in military|last=WAM|date=2012-07-08|website=GulfNews|access-date=2016-05-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/uae/uae-armed-forces-women-honoured|title=UAE Armed Forces women honoured {{!}} The National|website=www.thenational.ae|access-date=2016-05-19}} In 2014, women were had the choice to be conscripted provided they have their parents’ consent. Military service is for 9 months and is optional for women aged 18 to 30 and is mandatory for men aged between 18 and 30 and is for 1 year.{{cite web|url=https://www.wam.ae/en/news/emirates/1395268672475.html|title=Khawla Bint Al Azwar Military School is ready to welcome female conscripts {{!}} WAM|website=www.wam.ae|access-date=2016-05-19}} ==Europe== ===Denmark=== Women were employed in the Danish armed forces as early as 1934 with the Ground Observer Corps, Danish Women's Army Corps and Naval Corps in 1946 and the Women's Air Force since 1953. In 1962, the Danish parliament passed laws allowing women to volunteer in the regular Danish armed forces as long as they did not serve in units experiencing direct combat. 1971 saw the enlistment of women as non-commissioned officers, with military academies allowing women in 1974. In 1978, based on the reports of studies on the topic, women were allowed to enlist in an all areas of the Danish armed forces, with combat trials in the eighties exploring the capabilities of women in combat. In 1998, laws were passed allowing women to sample military life in the same way as conscripted men, however without being completely open to conscription. Since then females have served in infantry units in both Iraq and in combat in Afghanistan.{{cite web|url=http://sorensjogren.com/2012/the-problem-with-women-in-combat-units/|title=HugeDomains.com - SoreNsJogRen.com is for sale (Sore Ns Jog Ren)|website=sorensjogren.com}} Women in the Danish military come under the command of the Chief of Defense.{{cite web|url=http://www.nato.int/ims/2001/win/denmark.htm|title=NATO/IMS: Committee on Women in the NATO Forces: Denmark|publisher=}} As of January 2010, women make up 5% of the army, 6.9% of the navy, and 8.6% of air force personnel. ===Finland=== [[File:Naispunakaartilainen.jpg|thumb|125px|upright|Red Guard during the [[Finnish Civil War]]]] The [[Finnish Defense Forces]] does not conscript women. However, since 1995, women between 18 and 30 years of age have the possibility of voluntarily undertaking military service in the Defence Forces or in the [[Finnish Border Guard|Border Guard]]. Women generally serve under the same conditions as men. [[File:Lottia ilmavalvontatehtävissä.jpg|thumb|left|Members of [[Lotta Svärd]] in air control duty during the [[Continuation War]]]] The history of women in the Finnish military is, however, far longer than just since 1995. During the [[Finnish Civil War]], the [[Red Guards (Finland)|Reds]] had several ''Naiskaarti'' (Women's Guard) units made of voluntary 16- to 35-year-old women, who were given rudimentary military training. The reactions on women in military were ambivalent during the Civil War. The non-combat duties in Finnish Defence Forces [[peace-keeping]] operations opened to women in 1991. Since 1995 the women are allowed to serve in all combat arms including front-line infantry and special forces both in Finland and in operations outside Finland. ===France=== [[File:Cantiniere1800s.jpg|thumb|A [[Cantinière]] with a male infantry soldier in Algeria, around 1845. Painting by Edouard Moreau.]] In the 1800s, women in the French military were responsible for preparing meals for soldiers, and were called [[cantinière]]s. They sold food to soldiers beyond that which was given to them as rations. Cantinières had commissions from the administrators of the regiments, and they were required to be married to a soldier of the regiment. They served near the front lines on active campaigns, and some served for as long as 30 years.{{cite web|title=Following the drums: Cantinieres|url=http://www.napoleon-series.org/military/organization/c_cantinieres.html|accessdate=August 14, 2011}} During the [[Wars of the French Revolution]], some women enlisted in the army, mainly in support roles. [[Angélique Brûlon|Marie-Angélique Duchemin]] is the first woman with a recorded rank in the French Army, being promoted Corporal and Acting Sergeant in 1794. She was promoted 2nd Lieutenant on the retired list in 1815. Duchemin is the first woman decorated with the [[Legion of Honor]], in 1851.{{fr}} [http://www.napoleon.org/fr/salle_lecture/biographies/files/duchemin_delage_2007.asp fondation Napoléon] The role of women in the French military grew in 1914 with the recruitment of women as medical personnel (Service de Santé des Armées). In 1939, they were authorized to enlist with the armed service branches, and in 1972 their status evolved to share the same ranks as those of men. [[Valérie André]], a neurosurgeon, became the first woman in France to attain the rank of three-star general as Médecin Général Inspecteur. A veteran of the [[French Resistance]], she served overseas in [[Indochina]]. During that period, she learned how to pilot a helicopter so that she could reach wounded soldiers who were trapped in the jungle. André is the first woman to have flown a helicopter in combat. She received many decorations for her achievements, including the highest rank of the [[Legion of Honour]]. She retired from active service in 1981. Today women can serve in every position in the French military, including submarines[http://en.rfi.fr/france/20171204-France-have-its-first-women-submariners-mission France have its first women submariners on mission], [[Radio France International]], december 2017. and combat infantry.[http://www.rfi.fr/france/20150223-journee-internationale-femme-militaire-commando-parachutiste-8-mars-defense A l'armée, une femme est un homme comme les autres], Radio France international, march 2015 {{fr}} make up around 15% of all service personnel in the combined branches of the French military. They are 11% of the Army forces, 13% for the Navy, 21% of the Air Force and 50% of the Medical Corps. This is the highest proportion of female personnel in Europe.{{cite web|title=Les femmes de la Defense|url=https://www.defense.gouv.fr/content/download/487432/7798345/version/1/file/Les+femmes+dans+larmee+francaise-diptyque.pdf|publisher=Ministry of Defense, Government of France|accessdate=February 12, 2018}} ===Germany=== Since the creation of the [[Bundeswehr]] in 1955, Germany had employed one of the most conservative gender-policies of any NATO country.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} That was generally regarded as a reaction to the deployment of young women at the end of [[World War II]]. Though women were exempt from direct combat functions in accordance with Nazi-ideology, several hundred thousand German women, along with young boys and sometimes girls (as [[Flakhelfer]]), served in Luftwaffe artillery units; their flak shot down thousands of Allied warplanes.[http://americanhistoryprojects.com/downloads/H491/combat.pdf D'Ann Campbell, "Women in Combat: The World War Two Experience in the United States, Great Britain, Germany, and the Soviet Union" ''Journal of Military History'' (April 1993), 57:301-323]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In the year 1975 the first female medical officers were appointed in the ''Sanitätsdienst'' of the Bundeswehr. Since 1994, two women, [[Verena von Weymarn]] and Erika Franke, attained the rank of ''Generalarzt''. But it was not until January 2001 that women first joined German combat units, following a court ruling by the [[European Court of Justice]]. There are no restrictions regarding the branch of service, and there are woman serving in the "Fallschirmjäger" and as Tornado fighter pilot. ===Ireland=== In the Irish [[1916 Rising]], Cumann na mBan, the women's wing of the Irish Volunteers, fought alongside them in the streets of Dublin and in the General Post Office, the Irish Volunteers' HQ. [[Constance Markievicz]], an Irish Revolutionary and suffragette, commanded male and female troops during the Rising. The Defence (Amendment) (No. 2) Act, 1979, allowed women to join the [[Irish Defence Forces]] for the first time and was passed by the [[Oireachtas]] in 1979, making them the first European Armed Forces to allow women all roles in the military including combat roles, and even join the Irish Army Ranger Wing (Fianoglach), the Irish Special Forces, similar to the British SAS.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1979/en/act/pub/0028/index.html |title=Defence (Amendment) (No. 2) Act, 1979 |publisher=Irishstatutebook.ie |date=1979-11-06 |accessdate=2013-10-07}} There are no restrictions for women to the "full range of operational and administrative duties."{{cite web|url=http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/D/0658/D.0658.200807020061.html |title=Dáil Éireann - Volume 658 - 02 July, 2008 - Written Answers. - Defence Forces Personnel |publisher=Historical-debates.oireachtas.ie |date= |accessdate=2013-10-07}} As of January 2010 the number of women in the Permanent Defence Forces is 565, 5.7 percent of the total.[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/DDebate.aspx?F=DAL20100224.xml&Page=1&Ex=1236#N1236 ]{{dead link|date=October 2013}} ===Italy=== [[File:Italian Soldier Olypmic Games Turin 2006.jpg|thumb|upright=0.8|left|Italian parachutist]] During the short life of the [[Italian Social Republic]] (World War II), the Female Volunteer Unit was introduced as an auxiliary service and they were knwown as Female Auxiliary Unit ({{lang-it|Servizio Ausiliario Femminile}}). The law that introduced this unit provided that its existence be limited to war periods.{{cite web|url=http://web.tiscali.it/RSI_ANALISI/34.htm|title=Decreto istitutivo del Corpo femminile|access-date=30 September 2012}} Its equivalent in Southern Italy during World War II, was the ''CAF'', {{lang-it|Corpo di Assistenza Femminile}}, that was on the side of the [[Allies]]. This unit was also dismissed at the end of the war. Those who belonged to this unit were equivalent to [[sub-lieutenants]] and wore military uniforms made in [[Great Britain]].{{cite web|url=http://www.museobadoglio.altervista.org/docs/forze.pdf|title=Forze del Regno del Sud|access-date=30 September 2012}} In 1959, the Female Police unit ({{lang-it|Corpo di Polizia femminile}}) was established. In 1981, Diadora Bussani was the first woman who asked to be admitted into the Naval Academy of [[Livorno]] ({{lang-it|Accademia navale di Livorno}}). She was born in 1962 in [[Trieste]] and started her struggle to join the academy in 1981. After being excluded from the application, Italy's regional administrative court upheld the appeal; however, Italy's State Council overturned the judgment. The enlisting of a woman seemed to be legally feasible because of Italian law Legge 1963 n. 66 which allowed the enrollment of women in public positions, but the State Council excluded the military because of biological differences between male and female human bodies. When she became famous and the case was well-known, the [[United States Navy]] symbolically granted her enlistment on 2 November 1982.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloogger.it/2018/06/italiane-in-armi/|title=Italiane in armi|date=5 June 2018|publisher=}} Voluntary female military service was introduced in 1999 with the Italian law Legge 20 ottobre 1999 n. 380, which introduced the possibility of being admitted to the army for women.{{cite web|url=http://www.informagiovani.it/frame/_donnemiliti.htm|title=Servizio militare femminile|website=www.informagiovani.it}} Italy was the last country among [[NATO]] members to allow women to join the army.{{cite web|url=http://www.carabinieri.it/Internet/Editoria/Rassegna+Arma/2004/Suppl_3/I+Sessione/01_Sessione_03.htm#3|title=L'impatto del servizio militare femminile. Un primo bilancio (Periodico Rassegna dell'arma dei carabinieri anno anno 2004, supplemento al n. 3/2004|publisher=}} Nowadays women are present in all branches of Italian armed forces, including the police, and [[Guardia di Finanza]], and they are also employed for military missions abroad.{{cite web|url=http://www.difesa.it/APPROFONDIMENTI/ARCHIVIOAPPROFONDIMENTI/SERVIZIO_FEMMINILE/Pagine/default.aspx|title=Ministero della Difesa|publisher=}} Before the year 2000, women were employed in war only as voluntary nurses inside organizations [[Croce Rossa Italiana]] and ''Corpo delle infermiere volontarie dell'ACISMOM''. 235º Reggimento fanteria "Piceno" is the training center for women inside the Italian army.{{cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/organizzazione/capo-di-sme/comando-per-la-formazione-specializzazione-e-dottrina-dell-esercito/Scuola-di-Fanteria/Centro-Addestramento-Volontari/235-RAV-Piceno|title=235° Reggimento Addestramento Volontari|website=www.esercito.difesa.it}} ===Norway=== Women in Norway have been able to fill military roles since 1938, and during the Second World War both enlisted women and female officers served in all branches of the military. However, in 1947 political changes commanded that women only serve in civilian posts, with reservists allowing women to join them in 1959. Female personnel currently make up around 12% of the armed forces (2017).{{cite web|url=https://forsvaret.no/en/facts/the-armed-forces-in-numbers/personnel|title=Personnel|first=|last=Forsvaret|publisher=}} Between 1977 and 1984, the Norwegian Parliament passed laws expanding the role of women in the Norwegian Armed Forces, and in 1985 equal opportunities legislation was applied to the military. In 1995, Norway allowed women to serve on its military [[submarines]], and to this date there has been at least one female commander of a Norwegian submarine.{{cite web|url=http://www.nato.int/docu/review/2002/issue4/english/interview.html|title=Nato Review|publisher=}} The first was [[Solveig Krey]] in 1995.{{cite web|url=http://www.mil.no/fakta/start/menneskene/kvinner/ |title=Forsvarsnett: Kvinner |publisher=Mil.no |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} In 2015 conscription was extended to women making Norway the first [[NATO]] member and first European country to make national service compulsory for both men and women.{{cite web |url=https://forsvaret.no/en/newsroom/news-stories/female-conscription |title=Universal Conscription |publisher=Norwegian Armed Forces |date=11 June 2015 |access-date=25 June 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305005856/https://forsvaret.no/en/newsroom/news-stories/female-conscription |archive-date=5 March 2016 |dead-url=no}} ===Poland=== [[File:Zolnierki 1920.JPG|thumb|175px|Polish female volunteers during the [[Polish-Soviet War]]]] Women have taken part in the battles for independence against occupiers and invaders since at least the time of the [[Napoleonic Wars]]. During the occupation by the [[Nazi]]s, 1939–1945, several thousand women took part in the resistance movement as members of the [[Home Army]] and the [[Polish People's Army|People's Army]]. The Germans were forced to establish special [[prisoner-of-war camp]]s after the [[Warsaw Rising]] in 1944 to accommodate over a thousand women prisoners.{{cite web|url=http://www.polishresistance-ak.org/12%20Article.htm |title=Women in Home Army |publisher=Polishresistance-ak.org |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} In April 1938 the law requiring compulsory military service for men included provisions for voluntary service of women in auxiliary roles, in the medical services, in the anti-aircraft artillery and in communications. In 1939 a Women's Military Training Organization was established under the command of [[Maria Wittek]]. In present Poland a law passed April 6, 2004 requires all women with college nursing or veterinary degrees to register for compulsory service. In addition it allows women to volunteer and serve as professional personnel in all services of the army. As of June 30, 2007 there are 800 women in the army, of which 471 are officers, 308 non-commissioned officers and 21 other ranks, in addition 225 are in military training schools. Two active duty Polish women have achieved the rank of Colonel. [[Maria Wittek]] was the 1st Polish woman to reach the rank of General.[http://www.kadry.wp.mil.pl/artykul.php?idartykul=20 Women in army – in Polish] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090104013702/http://www.kadry.wp.mil.pl/artykul.php?idartykul=20 |date=January 4, 2009 }}[[:pl:Kobiety w Wojsku Polskim|in Polish]], Retrieved 2013-11-14{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=September 2015}} ===Russia=== {{Main|Women in the Russian and Soviet military}} [[File:Regiment from Petrograd.jpg|thumb|210px|[[Women's Battalion#1st Petrograd Women's Battalion|1st Petrograd Women's Battalion]] (1918)]] [[File:Military parade on Red Square 2017-05-09 028.jpg|thumb|Russian female cadets.]] During the [[First World War]], heavy defeats led to the loss of millions of [[Russian Empire|Russian Imperial]] soldiers. To psychologically energize morale [[Alexander Kerensky]] (leader of Russia of the [[Russian Provisional Government]]) ordered the creation of the Woman’s Death Battalion in May 1917. After three months of fighting, the size of this all-female unit fell from 2,000 to 250.{{cite web|url=http://www.spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk/Wdeath.htm |title=Women's Death Battalion |publisher=Spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} In November 1917, the [[Bolsheviks]] dissolved the unit. Shortly after Russia became part of the [[Soviet Union]] (see above for the role of woman in Soviet military) until December 1991. The current tally of woman in the Russian Army is standing at around 115,000 to 160,000, representing 10% of Russia’s military strength. ===Serbia=== {{commonscat|Military women of Serbia}} Although the Serbian armed forces were traditionally exclusively male (with exception of nurses and some other non-combat roles) there were some exceptions. Several women are known to have fought in the ranks in the [[Balkan Wars]] and the [[First World War]], often by initially hiding their gender to work around the draft regulations. The most notable of them was [[Milunka Savić]], the most decorated female combatant in history. In the [[Second World War]] [[Yugoslav Partisans|Yugoslav partisan units]] accepted female volunteers as combatants as well as medical personnel. After the war the practice was abandoned, but was reintroduced recently with professionalisation of the army. ===Sweden=== In the Military Articles of 1621, which organized the Swedish army, military men on all levels were explicitly allowed to bring their wives with them to war, as the wives were regarded to fill an important role as [[sutler]]s in the house hold organisation of the army: prostitutes, however, were banned.Sjöberg, Maria: ''Kvinnor i fält 1550-1850.'' [Women in Combat] Gidlund (2008) This regulation was kept until the Military Article of 1798, though the presence of women diminished after the end of the [[Great Northern War]]. In the Military Article of 1798, the only women allowed to accompany the army was the professional unmarried female sutlers, in Sweden named ''marketenterska''. Unofficially, however, there were females who served in the army posing as male the entire period, the most famous being [[Ulrika Eleonora Stålhammar]]. In 1924, the [[Swedish Women's Voluntary Defence Service]] (Swedish: Riksförbundet Sveriges lottakårer, commonly known as Lottorna) was founded: it is an auxiliary defense organization of the [[Swedish Home Guard]], a part of the [[Swedish Armed Forces]]. Since 1989 there are no gender restrictions in the Swedish military on access to military training or positions. They are allowed to serve in all parts of the military and in all positions, including combat.[http://www.rekryc.mil.se/article.php?id=11756 in Swedish, Retrieved 04-23-2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927045646/http://www.rekryc.mil.se/article.php?id=11756 |date=2007-09-27 }} Female personnel currently make up around 13% of the Armed Forces.Swedish Armed Forces http://www.forsvarsmakten.se/sv/om-myndigheten/vara-varderingar/jamstalldhet-och-jamlikhet/historik/ ===Turkey=== When Turkish history is examined, it is apparent that Turkish women have voluntarily taken tasks in the defence of their country, showing the same power and courage as men. [[Nene Hatun]], whose monument has been erected in the city of Erzurum (Eastern Turkey) because of her gallant bravery during the Ottoman-Russian War, constitutes a very good example of this fact. Besides providing nursery services, women also took main roles in combat in WWI.{{cite web |url=http://www.haznevi.net/Kavramoku.aspx?KID=589&KTID=6 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140913011056/http://www.haznevi.net/Kavramoku.aspx?KID=589&KTID=6 |archivedate=2014-09-13 |df= }} Furthermore, the Independence War has taken its place in history with the unsurpassed heroism of Turkish women.http://www.nato.int/ims/2001/win/turkey.htm [[Sabiha Gökçen]] was the first female combat pilot in the world, as well as the first Turkish female aviator. She was one of the eight adoptive children of [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]]. Throughout her career in the Turkish Air Force, Gökçen flew 22 different types of aircraft for more than 8,000 hours, 32 hours of which were active combat and bombardment missions. She was selected as the only female pilot for the poster of "20 Greatest Aviators in History" published by the United States Air Force in 1996.{{cite web|url=http://www.ctie.monash.edu.au/hargrave/gokcen.html |title=Sabiha Gokcen (1913-2001), Pioneer Aviatrix |publisher=Ctie.monash.edu.au |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} Women personnel are being employed as officers in the Turkish Armed Forces today. The women officers serve together with the men under the same respective chains of command. The personnel policy regarding women in the Turkish Armed Forces is based on the principle of "needing qualified women officers in suitable branches and ranks" to keep pace with technological advancements in the 21st century. Women civilian personnel have been assigned to the headquarters staff, technical fields, and social services without sexual discrimination.
